G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, this Court has subject matter jurisdiction because the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 2, because the cause of action arose in Lynn, Massachusetts, and Defendant conducts business there.

G.L. c. 148, \u00a7\u00a7 26E and 26F.proposition: Defendant, as landlord and property manager, was responsible for maintaining the common areas and ensuring that smoke detectors in hallways were operable and properly maintained, as required by G.L. c. 148, §§ 26E and 26F, and 527 C.M.R. 1.00 (Massachusetts Comprehensive Fire Safety Code).

527 C.M.R. 1.00.proposition: Defendant, as landlord and property manager, was responsible for maintaining the common areas and ensuring that smoke detectors in hallways were operable and properly maintained, as required by G.L. c. 148, §§ 26E and 26F, and 527 C.M.R. 1.00 (Massachusetts Comprehensive Fire Safety Code).

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 15.proposition: Defendant’s duty of care arises from both common law and statute, including but not limited to G.L. c. 186, § 15, G.L. c. 143, § 3T, and the Massachusetts State Fire Code, which collectively require landlords to ensure that required fire protection systems are functional.

G.L. c. 143, \u00a7 3T.proposition: Defendant’s duty of care arises from both common law and statute, including but not limited to G.L. c. 186, § 15, G.L. c. 143, § 3T, and the Massachusetts State Fire Code, which collectively require landlords to ensure that required fire protection systems are functional.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Award Plaintiff compensatory damages in an amount to be determined at trial, but not less than $12,500, plus interest as provided by G.L. c. 231, § 6B;

Mass. R. Civ. P. 54(d).proposition: Award costs of suit pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P. 54(d);

Mass. R. Civ. P. 38.proposition: Plaintiff demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable as of right under Mass. R. Civ. P. 38.

Mass. R. Civ. P. 11.proposition: I, the undersigned Plaintiff, certify that I have read the foregoing Complaint and that to the best of my knowledge, information, and belief, it is well‑grounded in fact and warranted by existing law or a good‑faith argument for the extension, modification, or reversal of existing law.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: A landlord in Massachusetts must act with reasonable care to maintain common areas in a safe condition for tenants and lawful visitors. Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is a leading Massachusetts case abolishing the common‑law distinction between invitees and licensees and imposing a general duty of reasonable care by occupiers toward lawful visitors. That principle underlies later cases holding landlords to a duty of reasonable care in maintaining common areas for tenants and their guests. However, the provided excerpt is only a concurrence about the treatment of trespassers and does not itself discuss landlords or common areas, so the support is indirect and via the case’s broader duty-of-care rule rather than this specific text.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: [From the main opinion, not shown in the excerpt provided:] The distinctions which the common law has drawn between invitees and licensees in determining the degree of care owed by an occupier of land are no longer appropriate. We hold that the proper test of the occupier’s liability is whether, in the management of his property, he has acted as a reasonable man in view of the probability of injury to others. This duty of reasonable care extends to all lawful visitors.

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.proposition: Under Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343, adopted in Massachusetts (see Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (2013)), a possessor of land is subject to liability for physical harm caused to invitees by a condition on the land if the possessor knows or should know of the condition and should realize it involves an unreasonable risk of harm.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly applies Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343A (closely related to § 343) and reiterates Massachusetts’ general premises-liability rule: a landowner owes a duty of reasonable care, including to maintain property in a reasonably safe condition and to warn of unreasonable dangers of which the landowner knows or should know. While the focus of the case is the ‘open and obvious’ exception, the court’s discussion presupposes and affirms that, under Massachusetts law, a possessor of land is liable for conditions posing unreasonable risks where the possessor knows or should know of the condition and risk. Thus, the case supports the Restatement-based proposition about duty to invitees, even though its primary holding concerns when that duty persists despite obviousness.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. This duty includes an obligation to maintain the ‘property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ … It also includes an obligation ‘to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.’”

Banaghan v. Dewey, 340 Mass. 73 (1959).proposition: Defendant’s failure to repair or replace the battery within a reasonable time constituted a breach of its duty under Massachusetts negligence law, including Banaghan v. Dewey, 340 Mass. 73 (1959) (landlord liable for failure to maintain common areas in safe condition); King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 658 (1977); Foster v. The Loft, Inc., 26 Mass. App. Ct. 289 (1988).
Banaghan v. Dewey, 340 Mass. 73 (1959).support_reasoning: Banaghan concerns a landlord’s and an elevator maintenance company’s duties to keep a common-area elevator in reasonably safe condition, including hidden mechanical defects, and holds that failure to properly inspect and maintain the elevator can constitute negligence. It does not address anything about repairing or replacing a battery, or about the timeliness of such a repair. Using Banaghan specifically for the proposition that failure to repair or replace a battery within a reasonable time is a breach of duty mischaracterizes the case’s holding, which is framed around elevator maintenance and landlord/common-area obligations, not battery repair timelines.
Banaghan v. Dewey, 340 Mass. 73 (1959).relevant_excerpt: Here the faulty governor and disconnected interlocks were defects not apparent to the tenants, and the fact, if it was a fact, that they were in the same inoperative condition at the time of the letting as they were when the accident occurred does not relieve the trustees of liability. Furthermore, there was evidence that the trustees had assumed a duty greater than that imposed under the common law rule. O’Brien, one of the trustee owners, testified that “it was part of the owners’ agreement with their tenants to maintain the front passenger elevator in a safe condition.”

King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 65.raw_text: King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 658 (1977)
King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 65.proposition: Defendant’s failure to repair or replace the battery within a reasonable time constituted a breach of its duty under Massachusetts negligence law, including Banaghan v. Dewey, 340 Mass. 73 (1959) (landlord liable for failure to maintain common areas in safe condition); King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 658 (1977); Foster v. The Loft, Inc., 26 Mass. App. Ct. 289 (1988).
King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 65.case_name: King v. G & M REALTY CORP.
King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 65.support_reasoning: King v. G & M Realty Corp. addresses a landlord’s general, continuing duty to exercise reasonable care to keep common areas (like a shared stairway) in a safe condition for tenants and lawful visitors. It does not involve or discuss any duty to repair or replace a battery, nor the concept of a ‘reasonable time’ to repair a specific defective item like a battery. The case therefore supports the broader negligence duty of landlords over common areas, but not the specific proposition about failure to repair or replace a battery within a reasonable time.
King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 65.relevant_excerpt: We think the measure of the landlord’s responsibility to the tenant with respect to common areas left in the landlord’s control should not differ in kind from that owed by the landlord to the tenant’s visitors. … The trial judge was thus correct in charging the jury as he did. There was no basis for allowing the motion for judgment, questions of negligence and contributory negligence being plainly for the jury… An indication of legislative policy consistent with our ruling may be found in G. L. c. 186, § 19… ‘within a reasonable time… exercise reasonable care to correct the unsafe condition….’

Foster v. The Loft, Inc., 26 Mass. App..raw_text: Foster v. The Loft, Inc., 26 Mass. App. Ct. 289 (1988)
Foster v. The Loft, Inc., 26 Mass. App..proposition: Defendant’s failure to repair or replace the battery within a reasonable time constituted a breach of its duty under Massachusetts negligence law, including Banaghan v. Dewey, 340 Mass. 73 (1959) (landlord liable for failure to maintain common areas in safe condition); King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 658 (1977); Foster v. The Loft, Inc., 26 Mass. App. Ct. 289 (1988).
Foster v. The Loft, Inc., 26 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a defendant’s failure to repair or replace a *battery* within a reasonable time and frames it as a breach of duty under Massachusetts negligence law. Foster v. The Loft, Inc. deals with negligent *retention* of an employee with a violent criminal record in a volatile bar environment, not with repair, replacement, or maintenance of physical equipment. While Foster does articulate general negligence/foreseeability principles, it does not address or establish any rule about failure to repair or replace a battery and thus does not support the proposition as stated.
Foster v. The Loft, Inc., 26 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “In these circumstances it was open to the jury to find that Loft was negligent in retaining Rida in his position as bartender, and that its action in doing so was the proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries. Assuming, as Loft asks us to do, that Loft had knowledge of the nature of Rida’s criminal record, it was open to the jury to find that Loft ‘took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.’”

Bernier v. Boston Edison Co., 380 Mass..raw_text: Bernier v. Boston Edison Co., 380 Mass. 372 (1980)
Bernier v. Boston Edison Co., 380 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s negligence was a direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries, as recognized under Bernier v. Boston Edison Co., 380 Mass. 372 (1980) (defendant liable for harm that was reasonably foreseeable result of its conduct).
Bernier v. Boston Edison Co., 380 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses causation and foreseeability, holding that Edison’s negligent pole design could be a legal cause of plaintiffs’ injuries if the harm was a reasonably foreseeable result of foreseeable vehicular impacts. The court affirms that negligence is actionable where it is a substantial factor in bringing about the injury and where the type of harm is within the scope of the foreseeable risk, even if the precise manner of the accident is not anticipated. This aligns with the proposition that a defendant is liable for harm that is the reasonably foreseeable result of its conduct.
Bernier v. Boston Edison Co., 380 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “Edison contends that its negligence, if any, must be taken not to have contributed in a legal sense to the plaintiffs’ injuries because Ramsdell was negligent… Impact of a car with a pole could be expected to occur as a result of driver negligence and the design of the pole must take such mishaps into account.… [T]o hold Edison liable the jury must conclude that Ramsdell was traveling, at impact, at a ‘reasonably foreseeable,’ i.e., nonexcessive speed. The precise manner of the accident need not have been foreseeable if impacts by moving vehicles were.”

Yee v. American National Ins. Co., 353 M.raw_text: Yee v. American National Ins. Co., 353 Mass. 358 (1967)
Yee v. American National Ins. Co., 353 M.proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries were foreseeable and preventable had Defendant exercised ordinary care. Yee v. American National Ins. Co., 353 Mass. 358 (1967).
Yee v. American National Ins. Co., 353 M.support_reasoning: The opinion in Yee v. American National Ins. Co. does not concern negligence, foreseeability, preventability of injuries, or any duty of ordinary care. It is a Massachusetts trust and estates construction case dealing with per capita vs. per stirpes distribution at the termination of a trust. The cited proposition about foreseeability of plaintiff’s injuries is unrelated to the issues actually decided, so the citation does not support that proposition.
Yee v. American National Ins. Co., 353 M.relevant_excerpt: "The language of the termination gift, read literally, directs a per capita distribution among the children of B, C, and D (with the son of D's deceased child taking the share which his parent would have taken). During C's life (and after the death of B and D), income was distributed to C and to the issue of B and D essentially on a per stirpes basis. This, however, does not sufficiently show an intent contrary to the literal meaning of the termination gift."

LeBlanc v. Logan Hilton Joint Venture, 4.raw_text: LeBlanc v. Logan Hilton Joint Venture, 463 Mass. 316 (2012)
LeBlanc v. Logan Hilton Joint Venture, 4.proposition: Plaintiff’s status as a residential tenant places her squarely within the class of persons the statutory duties were intended to protect. LeBlanc v. Logan Hilton Joint Venture, 463 Mass. 316 (2012).
LeBlanc v. Logan Hilton Joint Venture, 4.case_name: LeBlanc v. Logan Hilton Joint Venture
LeBlanc v. Logan Hilton Joint Venture, 4.support_reasoning: The opinion involves an electrician working at a hotel and addresses architects’ and engineers’ tort duties arising from a construction contract and contribution/indemnity issues. It does not concern residential premises, landlord‑tenant relationships, or define a statutory class of protected residential tenants. Nothing in the reasoning frames the plaintiff as a residential tenant or analyzes whether statutory duties were intended to protect such a class, so the case does not support the stated proposition.
LeBlanc v. Logan Hilton Joint Venture, 4.relevant_excerpt: “It is settled that a claim in tort may arise from a contractual relationship, . . . and may be available to persons who are not parties to the contract. ... [A] defendant under a contractual obligation ‘is liable to third persons not parties to the contract who are foreseeably exposed to danger and injured as a result of its negligent failure to carry out that obligation.’” (LeBlanc v. Logan Hilton Joint Venture, 463 Mass. 316, 328–329).

Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).proposition: Defendant’s inaction also breached its implied warranty of habitability and duty to maintain safe premises recognized in Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).support_reasoning: Young v. Garwacki recognizes and adopts a general common‑law negligence duty for landlords to exercise reasonable care in maintaining even the demised premises, including toward a tenant’s guest. It does not itself ground liability in an ‘implied warranty of habitability’ in this case, nor does it frame the landlord’s obligation as a separate ‘duty to maintain safe premises’ arising from that warranty; the warranty is discussed descriptively and contrasted with negligence. Thus, using Young as authority that inaction breached an implied warranty of habitability misstates the basis of the decision, which is negligence, not warranty.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).relevant_excerpt: “Today, we do away with the ancient law that bars a tenant’s guest from recovering compensation from a landlord for injuries caused by negligent maintenance of areas rented to the tenant… Henceforth, landlords as other persons must exercise reasonable care not to subject others to an unreasonable risk of harm. A landlord must act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances… Henceforth, this basic principle of responsibility applies to Massachusetts landlords as well.”
